Letter to Federation of Hospital Workers Unions
articles.content:
U.S. President's special envoy to visit DPRK 
   Pyongyang, May 22 (KCNA) -- William Perry, special adviser to U.S. President Clinton, will visit the DPRK from May 25 to 28, Juche 88 (1999) as his special envoy.
    He will be accompanied by an ambassador of the State Department, a director of the National Security Council, White House, and a general of the Defense Department and others.
    During the visit the envoy will exchange with the DPRK side opinions on issues concerning the relations between the two countries.

articles.title: "Arirang Festival" in Tokyo

articles.content:
"Arirang Festival" in Tokyo
   Pyongyang, May 22 (KCNA) -- An "Arirang Festival" was held in Tokyo on May 16 on the theme of the independent and peaceful reunification of Korea and Korea-Japan friendship, according to Joson Sinbo published in Japan.   Present there were first vice-chairman of the central standing committee of the General Association of Korean Residents in Japan (Chongryon) So Man Sul and other Chongryon officials and compatriots in Japan, South Koreans staying in Japan, public officials and people from all walks of life of Japan.   
The opening ceremony of the festival was addressed by Ku Pon Hon, chairman of the festival executive committee, Banri Kaieta, member of the House of Representatives of Japan, Ryosho Hayashi, chief director of the Japan-Korea Cultural Interchange Association, and other public figures of Japan.
   Colorful events were held at the festival. Among them were performances of the Kumgangsan Opera Troupe and other local song and dance groups and street  performances by students of Korean schools.

articles.title: Revision of "foreigners registration law" called for
articles.content:
Japanese map marking Tok Islet as Korean one 
   Pyongyang, May 22 (KCNA) -- It has been brought to light that Tok Islet was clearly marked as belonging to Korea on an atlas which was worked out by a Japanese renowned map maker Seizo Ito and published in Tokyo in 1910, according to the South Korean newspaper Hangyore.   Prof. Ri Jin Myong who has studied the "issue of claim to Tok Islet" opened to the public a "complete map of Korea" and a "complete map of Shimane Prefecture, Japan" from a "large atlas of imperial Japanese prefectures", which is kept at a state library in France.

articles.content:
Revision of "foreigners registration law" called for
   Pyongyang, May 22 (KCNA) -- Representatives of the Human Rights Association of Koreans in Japan visited the Hall of the House of Councilors of Japan on May 17 and demanded the fundamental revision of the "foreigners registration law", according to Joson Sinbo published in Japan.   
   They said that the issue of the legal status of Koreans in Japan is not referred to in a draft amendment to the "law" which is under consideration at the Japanese diet. 
They handed to the chairman and members of the judicial committee of the House of Councilors a letter of request for the fundamental revision of the "law" addressed to the Minister of Justice of Japan.
   Earlier, they submitted a similar letter to the Ministry of Justice of Japan.

articles.title: S. Korean workers' struggle supported
Present ruler and Kwangju  murderer assailed
articles.content:
S. Korean workers' struggle supported
   Pyongyang, May 22 (KCNA) -- Workers in the North Korea expressed support and solidarity with South Korean workers  in their struggle for vital rights and democracy.   Meetings were held separately at the central district public building construction office in Pyongyang, the west Pyongyang locomotive unit and Pyongyang Steel Works over May 18-20.
   Speakers said that the massive  struggle of workers and other people in different places of South Korea were an eruption of pent-up grudge and wrath against the rulers who have trampled underfoot the elementary right to existence and democracy and plunged them into the abyss of death.

DPRK delegation leaves for Nigeria
   Pyongyang, May 22 (KCNA) -- The DPRK delegation headed by Yang Hyong Sop, vice-president of the presidium of the Supreme People's Assembly (SPA), left here today by air to participate in the inaugural ceremony of the Nigerian President.
    It was seen off by Kim Yun Hyok, general secretary of the presidium of the SPA, and Pak Kil Yon, vice-Minister of Foreign Affairs.
